OF
WINNERS
FRESHMEN
INTERCLASS
ANNUAL
TRACK MEET
Victors Score 70 Points; Juniors
Second With 40; Captain Heyn
Individual Star

The freshmen easily emerged as
victors from the interclass track
meet held last Friday afternoon at
Homewood Field with a total of 70
points. The Juniors were second
with 41 points, and the Sophomores
took third place with 23 points.
Fourth place was taken by the Seniors with 19 points. The whole
meet was run off in competition
with a baseball game between Baltimore City College and Hopkins.
The interest of the spectators was
about equally divided.
The 220-yard dash won by
Thompson,'28, was run in 23.4 sec.,
which was good time considering
it is early in the season and that
the race was run on a slow track.
Gwinn, '27, had no difficulty in
winning the one mile- and two-mile
races. Gwinn started at scratch,
giving his opponents a quarter lap
handicap in the mile and a half lap
handicap in the two mile.
Edwards Wins Dash

Edwards, .a graduate student,
won the 880-yard dash, but the
points for first place went to Garris, '27, who came in second.
Graff, '28, won the shot put with
a 6 foot handicap over Gilpin, '26,
who took second place. Gilpin also
won the discus throw with a throw
of 104.6 feet.
Birley, '26, and Blades, '23, tied
for first place in the high jump at
5 feet 4 inches. Blades cut his leg
in an attempt to clear the bar and
was forced to withdraw from the
contest for a short time.
To Captain Heyn, '26, belong the
honors for the highest invividual
score. Heyn won 16 points in five
events. Pierce, '28, was a close
second with 13 points, followed by
Graff, '28, one of his team-mates,
with 11 points. Gwinn, '27, was
fourth with 10 points. Conning

HOMEWOOD, BALTIMORE, MD., APRIL 7, 1925

VOL XXIX, No 46

SPRING FOOTBALL
PRACTICE PLANNED
Spring football practice
will be held at Strouse field
every Monday, Wednesday,
and Friday following the.
Easter recess. These practices, which will be under the
supervision of George Darley of the Physical Training
Department, are to be held
for new candidates and members of last year's squad who
are not actively participating
in some spring sport.
"These practices are not to
interfere with lacrosse, baseball or track. The main purpose is to give me a line on
next year's material," said
Coach Van Orman.

DR. PFUND EXPERIMENTS
WITH LIQUID AIR
AT ASSEMBLY
Uncanny Feats Accomplished
Physics Instructor at
Weekly Meeting

by

To those students not initiated
into the mysteries of liquid air the
assembly last Thursday was particularly entertaining. Dr. A. Herman Pfund, Associate Professor
of Physics at Johns Hopkins, was
lecturer, humorist, and magician
all in one. His jokes were funny,
the technical facts he gave out
were interesting, and the things he
did were downright uncanny.
To demonstrate the extremely
low temperature of liquid air, Dr.
Pfund poured some from a specially constructed flask into a teakettle, set the tea-kettle on a piece
of ice, stepped back, and complacently watched the steam come
DR. IRA REMSEN RETURNS roaring out of the spout. Maybe
it wasn't steam, but who cares to
FOR VISIT
be disillusioned?
Last

of Original Faculty
Chemical Laboratory

Views

Urged by letter and by personal
invitation, Dr. Ira Remsen, former President of the University,
came to Baltimore last Wednesday evening with a two-fold purpose in mind: to speak before the
Section of the History of Chemistry of the American Chemical Society here next Thursday and to
see his old friends and the new
chemical laboratory at Homewood.
Everything has been done to
make Dr. Remsen feel perfectly
at home. A special office in the
chemical laboratory building has
been furnished completely with all
the old furniture of Dr. Remsen's
former office in, the old building
downtown. He was well pleased
with his new quarters, and said
so.
Dr. Remsen is the only man left
out of the original faculty of Hopkins. He was for eleven years,
1901 to 1912, president of the university and for over 25 years head
of the chemistry department.

Lacrosse Defense Shows Up Well
While Attack Proves Strong
Despite Injuries

Starting the season rather inauspiciously the Johns Hopkins
baseball nine was defeated by the
University of Richmond tossers 9
to 5 at Homewood Saturday. Although the game started evenly it
ended in a one-sided victory for
the Southerners. Coach Brockman's team, however, showed capable ability against the nine that
defeated Navy,

Playing the first game of the
1925 season, the Johns Hopkins
lacrosse team defeated the L'Hirondelle Club, 4 to 2, Saturday.
The game, although not particularly fast, was as close as the
score indicates and held the interest of the well-filled grand).
Amid.
Captain Douglas Turnbull was
tht individual star of the game
for Hopkins, scoring half its
goals. With the first whistle the
ball was run into L'Hirondelle's
territory, beginning the aggressive type of play that characterized the game. Turnbull, leading
the well-coordinated Black and
Blue attack, received a pass from
Max Cone and scored the first
goal of the season in less than
four minutes of play.

Congratulations! After a lapse
of nearly a year, the editorials of
your sheet have begun to assume
some semblance of the professional touch. Great stuff.
But why not have the ancient
campus publicity agent tell the
managers of publications, clubs,
committee, teams, and the faculty
to go to hell, and print the news
from an unbiased standpoint?

Some benevolent deity must have watched over Homewood
Field while the contagious ills of intercollegiate sports have been
prevalent. Unhurt by the stadium craze, Homewood has remained the modest athletic field of a modest student body. In
the course of a year practically half the entire undergraduate
body—to say nothing of swarms of preparatory school students
—receive some form of bodily exercise at Homewood.
At the present time approximately one hundred undergraduates are engaged daily in lacrosse, baseball, and track practice.
Last- Friday, in the inter-class Track Meet, the entire student
body was given an opportunity for healthy outdoor exercise.
Other colleges may point *ith pride to "wins"; but we
should feel a surge of self-respect when we realize that there
are men on the Red Eagles who have been members of the
squad—merely this and nothing more—for the whole of their
undergraduate career.
Other colleges may have only two per cent of their students
engaged in athletics; let the curious ask "Doc" Rhodes, the
trainer, how many pairs of legs he rubs down each
day..
When we beat Navy and Maryland this spring we should
regard the victories as incidental—pleasant and worth working
for, to be sure, but only incidental.

The next issue of The News-Letter will appear on the
campus Friday, April- 17. Copy for this issue will be due at
the office 10 A. M., Tuesday, April 14.

wings that brushed the ears of

Rodgers and "Bob" Van Horn,
accompanied by Carl Lausch at
the piano, delegated an informally
arranged audience with some
dance ditties. Rodgers of tailormade fame, assisted by Van
Horn's novel tenor, admirably
rendered "Mammy," "Dear One"
and other snatches. Soon a large
aggregation of appreciation barnhounds had formed a ring about
the performers.
This was no insignificant episode. It was rather a glorious
outburst of long hibernated pep.

MR. EDWIN BOK PRAISES
PAGE SCHOOL
Commenting on the Page
School, Mr. Bok, as reported in
the Baltimore Sun, said,"Any institution which means the development of the international mind
in the United States will not only
be a needful addition to our national life, but an imperative one.
Our wise policies of the future
whether foreign or domestic, will
depend upon an intelligent knowledge of the financial, economic,
and spiritual conditions of the
peoples of the world. We must
recognize that our isolation from
other nations is over."

OF
WINNERS
FRESHMEN
INTERCLASS
ANNUAL
TRACK MEET
Victors Score 70 Points; Juniors
Second With 40; Captain Heyn
Individual Star

The freshmen easily emerged as
victors from the interclass track
meet held last Friday afternoon at
Homewood Field with a total of 70
points. The Juniors were second
with 41 points, and the Sophomores
took third place with 23 points.
Fourth place was taken by the Seniors with 19 points. The whole
meet was run off in competition
with a baseball game between Baltimore City College and Hopkins.
The interest of the spectators was
about equally divided.
The 220-yard dash won by
Thompson,'28, was run in 23.4 sec.,
which was good time considering
it is early in the season and that
the race was run on a slow track.
Gwinn, '27, had no difficulty in
winning the one mile- and two-mile
races. Gwinn started at scratch,
giving his opponents a quarter lap
handicap in the mile and a half lap
handicap in the two mile.
Edwards Wins Dash

Edwards, .a graduate student,
won the 880-yard dash, but the
points for first place went to Garris, '27, who came in second.
Graff, '28, won the shot put with
a 6 foot handicap over Gilpin, '26,
who took second place. Gilpin also
won the discus throw with a throw
of 104.6 feet.
Birley, '26, and Blades, '23, tied
for first place in the high jump at
5 feet 4 inches. Blades cut his leg
in an attempt to clear the bar and
was forced to withdraw from the
contest for a short time.
To Captain Heyn, '26, belong the
honors for the highest invividual
score. Heyn won 16 points in five
events. Pierce, '28, was a close
second with 13 points, followed by
Graff, '28, one of his team-mates,
with 11 points. Gwinn, '27, was
fourth with 10 points. Conning

HOMEWOOD, BALTIMORE, MD., APRIL 7, 1925

VOL XXIX, No 46

SPRING FOOTBALL
PRACTICE PLANNED
Spring football practice
will be held at Strouse field
every Monday, Wednesday,
and Friday following the.
Easter recess. These practices, which will be under the
supervision of George Darley of the Physical Training
Department, are to be held
for new candidates and members of last year's squad who
are not actively participating
in some spring sport.
"These practices are not to
interfere with lacrosse, baseball or track. The main purpose is to give me a line on
next year's material," said
Coach Van Orman.

DR. PFUND EXPERIMENTS
WITH LIQUID AIR
AT ASSEMBLY
Uncanny Feats Accomplished
Physics Instructor at
Weekly Meeting

by

To those students not initiated
into the mysteries of liquid air the
assembly last Thursday was particularly entertaining. Dr. A. Herman Pfund, Associate Professor
of Physics at Johns Hopkins, was
lecturer, humorist, and magician
all in one. His jokes were funny,
the technical facts he gave out
were interesting, and the things he
did were downright uncanny.
To demonstrate the extremely
low temperature of liquid air, Dr.
Pfund poured some from a specially constructed flask into a teakettle, set the tea-kettle on a piece
of ice, stepped back, and complacently watched the steam come
DR. IRA REMSEN RETURNS roaring out of the spout. Maybe
it wasn't steam, but who cares to
FOR VISIT
be disillusioned?
Last

of Original Faculty
Chemical Laboratory

Views

Urged by letter and by personal
invitation, Dr. Ira Remsen, former President of the University,
came to Baltimore last Wednesday evening with a two-fold purpose in mind: to speak before the
Section of the History of Chemistry of the American Chemical Society here next Thursday and to
see his old friends and the new
chemical laboratory at Homewood.
Everything has been done to
make Dr. Remsen feel perfectly
at home. A special office in the
chemical laboratory building has
been furnished completely with all
the old furniture of Dr. Remsen's
former office in, the old building
downtown. He was well pleased
with his new quarters, and said
so.
Dr. Remsen is the only man left
out of the original faculty of Hopkins. He was for eleven years,
1901 to 1912, president of the university and for over 25 years head
of the chemistry department.

HOMEWOOD SATURDAY
Lacrosse Team Bests L'Hirondelle Club, 4 to 2,
But Richmond, Conqueror of Navy,
Leads Ball Tossers, 9 to 5
[DETAILED SCORES CAN BE FOUND ON PAGE 3]
to

Lacrosse Defense Shows Up Well
While Attack Proves Strong
Despite Injuries

Starting the season rather inauspiciously the Johns Hopkins
baseball nine was defeated by the
University of Richmond tossers 9
to 5 at Homewood Saturday. Although the game started evenly it

Congratulations! After a lapse
of nearly a year, the editorials of
your sheet have begun to assume
some semblance of the professional touch. Great stuff.
But why not have the ancient
campus publicity agent tell the
managers of publications, clubs,
committee, teams, and the faculty
to go to hell, and print the news
from an unbiased standpoint?

Some benevolent deity must have watched over Homewood
Field while the contagious ills of intercollegiate sports have been
prevalent. Unhurt by the stadium craze, Homewood has remained the modest athletic field of a modest student body. In
the course of a year practically half the entire undergraduate
body—to say nothing of swarms of preparatory school students
—receive some form of bodily exercise at Homewood.
At the present time approximately one hundred undergraduates are engaged daily in lacrosse, baseball, and track practice.
Last- Friday, in the inter-class Track Meet, the entire student
body was given an opportunity for healthy outdoor exercise.
Other colleges may point *ith pride to "wins"; but we
should feel a surge of self-respect when we realize that there
are men on the Red Eagles who have been members of the
squad—merely this and nothing more—for the whole of their
undergraduate career.
Other colleges may have only two per cent of their students
engaged in athletics; let the curious ask "Doc" Rhodes, the
trainer, how many pairs of legs he rubs down each
day..
When we beat Navy and Maryland this spring we should
regard the victories as incidental—pleasant and worth working
for, to be sure, but only incidental.

The next issue of The News-Letter will appear on the
campus Friday, April- 17. Copy for this issue will be due at
the office 10 A. M., Tuesday, April 14.

MR. EDWIN BOK PRAISES
PAGE SCHOOL
Commenting on the Page
School, Mr. Bok, as reported in
the Baltimore Sun, said,"Any institution which means the development of the international mind
in the United States will not only
be a needful addition to our national life, but an imperative one.
Our wise policies of the future
whether foreign or domestic, will
depend upon an intelligent knowledge of the financial, economic,
and spiritual conditions of the
peoples of the world. We must
recognize that our isolation from
other nations is over."
